Rapid streptococcal antigen test can confirm the presence of group A Streptococcus in the pharynx and guide the use of antibiotics. Elevated C-reactive protein is non-specific and cannot be used for diagnosis. Detection of antistreptolysin titer and echocardiography are indicated for rheumatic fever, which is a complication of streptococcal pharyngitis but is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient.
